pageData.text: The organ systems are intricately interconnected and work together to operate a functioning organism. In this investigation, the student will be guided through the dissection and close examination of a fetal pig. These activities are intended to provide an overview of organ systems and actively encourage the student to apply anatomical terminology throughout the exercise.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: List characteristics of modern mammals in general and specifically artiodactyls, and identify them in the fetal pig.
Examine the external anatomy of the fetal pig, and identify the sex from external structures.
Apply anatomical terminology when performing a dissection of a fetal pig.
Identify internal structures, and classify them according to organ system.
Summarize the function of organs and organ systems observed during the dissection.

pageData.text: It has been suggested that xenotransplantation, or cross-species transplantation, with pigs could help fill the growing demand of patients waiting for organ transplants. In 1838, the first pig corneal xenotransplantation was performed on a human patient. Although much of the research regarding xenotransplantation in the last few centuries has focused on non-human primates, pigs, humans, and chimpanzees are all genetically similar.

Recent advancements in gene editing have made it possible to insert human genes into pigs. Using the CRISPR–Cas9 genome editing system, inserting human genes into pigs reduces the risk of pig organ rejection. The first pig <button class='glossary-text'>heart</button> was implanted into a U.S. patient in January 2022<sup>1</sup>. Using pig valves in heart surgery is already common and pig organ transplantation may soon be routine.

1Rabin, R.C. (2022, January 10). In a First, Man Receives a Heart from a Genetically Altered Pig. The New York Times.
https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/10/health/heart-transplant-pig-bennett.html

pageData.subTitle: The Pig as an Anatomical Model
pageData.text: The domestic pig, Sus scrofa, is a member of the class Mammalia. Mammals are identified by the presence of two characteristics: hair and mammary glands. Modern mammals (those living today) also are distinguished from other vertebrates by the presence or absence of several other structures. Mammals have a single dentary bone, the (jawbone), which articulates with the squamosal bone, or the cheek area in the skull. With the exception of toothed whales, mammals have (two or more types of teeth, e.g., molars and canines). There are three bones in the middle ear cavity, and most mammals have a (1) (outer ear). A muscular aids in respiration. Most mammals have sweat glands. Monotremes (the platypus and the echidna) are the only mammals with a cloaca and the only ones that lay eggs. Mammalian blood marrow produces enucleated (without a nucleus), round red blood cells (camelids have elongated red blood cells). The right, fourth aortic arch (which forms the arch of the aorta) of mammals is much reduced; what little remains is part of the right subclavian artery.

Pigs are members of the order Artiodactyla, which contains ungulates (hoofed mammals) with an even number of toes. Artiodactyla also include cattle and deer. Pigs are omnivorous, eating both plants and animals. The natural life span of domestic pigs is 15 to 20 years, and they can reach up to 400 kg (900 lb) in weight. In the U.S., most pigs are slaughtered at 4 to 10 months of age.
The pig estrous cycle is 21 days, and gestation is 112 to 115 days. Sows give birth to an average of 7 to 12 piglets per litter.

Pigs have many anatomical and physiological characteristics that are similar to humans. Many drugs used in modern medicine have been tested on pigs. Many surgical techniques were perfected using pigs before being performed on humans. Pig body parts have even been transplanted into humans. <button class='glossary-text'>Heart</button> valve replacements were obtained from pigs prior to the development of high-quality artificial replacements. Pig skin often was used as a temporary skin graft for human burn victims. Pig anatomy is an excellent example of typical mammalian anatomy and is similar to human anatomy in many ways.

pageData.subTitle: External Features
pageData.text: The skin performs a variety of important functions. It acts as a barrier to ultraviolet radiation, harmful substances, and disease-producing organisms. It helps to prevent the loss of water from the body, aids in body temperature regulation, is an excretory organ (e.g., sweat), and serves as a receptor for external stimuli via embedded nerve endings and sensory structures. The skin provides storage for reserve nutrients and is the site of vitamin D production. It consists of two layers: the epidermis is the outer layer, and the dermis is the deeper layer. Hair follicles, several types of glands, various sense organs, blood vessels, and nerves also are present in the skin. Hooves are modifications of the epidermis. Note that the pig (11) has four toes and that a pig walks on the middle two toes on each foot.

The external ear (<button class='glossary-text'>pinna</button>) channels sound waves into the external auditory meatus, the small opening in the ear. Sound then travels through a short passage, the auditory canal, to the eardrum (tympanic membrane). Sound vibrations are transmitted from the eardrum to specialized nerve endings in the cochlea.

The provided the attachment to the placenta when the fetal pig was in the sow’s uterus. The placenta is a fetomaternal organ that serves as an area of interaction between the circulatory systems of the mother and fetus. The umbilical cord contains three blood vessels: one (11) and two (17). These vessels are embedded in gelatinous connective tissue. The umbilical vein carries nutrient and oxygen-rich blood from the placenta to the developing fetus. The two umbilical arteries carry waste-laden blood to the placenta, where the wastes pass across into the mother’s blood. Normally, maternal and fetal blood do not mix.

In males, the urogenital opening is immediately to the umbilical cord and is the opening for the penis. The (21) is a sac of skin to the (20) and between the hind legs. The scrotum contains the in mature male pigs. In a young pig, the testes may not have fully descended from the abdominal cavity into the scrotum. Females also have a urogenital opening, which serves both the reproductive and urinary organs. The labia are the small folds on either side of the opening. These labia come together ventral to the anus to form a small spikelike projection, the (19). The clitoris is on the interior side of the papilla. The clitoris is an erectile organ homologous to the male penis.

pageData.subTitle: Respiratory System
pageData.text: The respiratory system goes from the nasal cavity through the into the , which becomes the bronchus that split into the . The digestive system and the respiratory system both share the nasopharynx, after which they split into the (18) and the (20). The larynx is the hard, enlarged region of the trachea (19). Fibrous cords are present in the larynx. Sound is produced as these cords vibrate when air passes over them. The trachea is the tube that connects the lungs (5) to the nasopharynx. It is reinforced with rings of cartilage that prevent collapse. The trachea is lined with ciliated cells that trap mucus and foreign particles, and move them back to the oral cavity. The esophagus is a second tube that is immediately to the trachea. The esophagus is part of the digestive system. The trachea enters the lungs, where it branches into two tubes. Each of these bronchial tubes is a bronchus (plural, bronchi). Deeper inside the lungs, the bronchial tubes divide into secondary bronchi, then into bronchioles, and finally into very fine tubes that lead to microscopic air sacs (alveoli). Gas exchange occurs in the alveoli. The lungs are a pair of highly vascularized organs. Each lung is divided into sections known as lobes. There are four lobes on the right side and three on the left.

A dome-shaped muscle separates the abdominal cavity from the . This structure is the (12). In the fetal pig, it is a sheet of muscle attached around its perimeter to the body wall. The lungs and (4) are to the diaphragm. The (7), (6), and other abdominal viscera are to the diaphragm. It is responsible for the physical movement that occurs during breathing. The diaphragm moves downward as it contracts, which increases the size of the thoracic cavity. The diaphragm returns to its original position when it relaxes, and the thoracic cavity decreases in size. This increase and decrease in the size of the thoracic cavity acts as a bellows. Air is pulled in (inhalation) when the cavity increases in size, and air is forced out (exhalation) when it decreases in size.

pageData.subTitle: Digestive System
pageData.text: Digestion and the digestive system begin in the mouth. Food is torn and broken by the teeth when it enters the mouth. Saliva lubricates the food and contains digestive enzymes that begin the process of breaking down complex molecules into simple ones that can be absorbed in the digestive tract. The hard and soft palates prevent food from entering the nasal cavity. The hard palate is <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> to the soft palate. Breathing is interrupted for only a brief instant to allow food to pass from the mouth to the <button class='glossary-text'>esophagus</button>. During this brief interval, the epiglottis flips back over the tracheal opening, and the throat muscles push the food into the esophagus. The esophagus passes through the <button class='glossary-text'>thoracic cavity</button> behind the <button class='glossary-text'>trachea</button> and attaches to the <button class='glossary-text'>stomach</button>. The stomach is a large, bean-shaped, muscular, saclike organ. The stomach wall is composed of a lining containing glands. This lining is surrounded by three layers of muscle oriented in different directions: a longitudinal outer layer, a circular middle layer, and an oblique inner layer. Glands in the stomach lining produce and secrete digestive juices, principally hydrochloric acid and pepsin. These substances are involved in breaking down food. Food first enters the stomach at the cardiac region.

The cardiac sphincter, a ring of muscle, is located at the junction of the stomach and the esophagus. This sphincter contracts to prevent food from passing back up into the esophagus. The surface of the stomach contains a pocket that is common in pigs but rare in humans. This structure is a . Fetal mammals constantly swallow amniotic fluid. This fluid, along with mucus and cells from the skin and digestive tract, is dark green and is called meconium. The pyloric sphincter is located at the end of the stomach. This additional sphincter forms the junction between the stomach and the (10) and allows food to pass through for further digestion.

The (15) and the (8) are next to the stomach. The spleen is a brown, oblong, firm organ located along the greater curvature of the stomach. It is part of the lymphatic system and is not a digestive organ. This highly vascularized organ filters the blood. The spleen’s outer surface is covered by a capsule of connective tissue and smooth muscle. The interior of the spleen is filled with a complex network of connective tissue, nerves, blood vessels, and the highly vascularized splenic pulp. After birth, the spleen produces white blood cells, removes old red blood cells, and produces antibodies. In the fetus, the spleen is the primary site of red blood cell production.

The is a slender tube that emerges from the pyloric end of the . It then continues as a long, coiled tube until it reaches the (9). The small intestine of the fetal pig may be one to two meters (three to six feet) long. It is divided into three sections: the , the , and the . The duodenum is adjacent to the stomach. It is the shortest section of the small intestine. The jejunum is the longest section of the small intestine and is located after the duodenum. The ileum is the terminal section of the small intestine. The ileum joins the large intestine. The ileocecal valve, a sphincter located at the junction of the ileum and the large intestine, prevents material from passing prematurely into the large intestine. The small intestine interior wall has a velvety appearance. This appearance is due to many thousands of circular folds and hundreds of thousands of villi on the folds. These structures provide a very large surface area for absorption of nutrients from digested food, which occurs only in the small intestine. The process of digestion occurs mostly in the small intestine. Gastric juices mix with salivary juices and food in the stomach. Fats, proteins, and starches are broken down predominantly by the digestive juices of the , the , and the small intestine.

The pancreas fits into the c-shaped curve of the small intestine where it joins the stomach. It’s an elongated, granular structure that is lighter in color than the intestines or stomach. The pancreas is a dual-function gland. It is an endocrine gland (secretes into the blood-stream) and an exocrine gland (secretes through a duct). As an exocrine gland, the pancreas secretes pancreatic juice through a duct into the small intestine. This juice contains a number of enzymes essential for the digestion of food and is released into the small intestine through the pancreatic duct. As an endocrine gland, the pancreas secretes into the bloodstream three hormones that regulate blood sugar levels. Insulin is essential for normal carbohydrate metabolism. Insulin is secreted into the bloodstream when the level of sugar in the blood rises, which results in an increase in the uptake of blood sugar by cells and a decrease in the level of blood sugar. Glucagon has the opposite effect. Glucagon is secreted when there is a decline in the level of blood sugar. Glucagon causes an immediate but short-lived increase in blood sugar. Insulin and glucagon work together to regulate blood sugar levels. The third hormone is somatostatin, which inhibits the release of glucagon and insulin.

The cecum is located just beyond the junction of the small intestine and large intestine. Unlike in most herbivorous mammals, the pig cecum does not have an important role in digestion. In humans, the cecum terminates at the appendix.

The is divided into the spiral colon, the ascending colon, the descending colon, the rectum, and the . The spiral colon is the longest portion of the large intestine. It resembles a coiled spring. It is located to the left side of the (16). The next portion is the ascending colon. It is located immediately to the right of the midline of the abdomen. As the name suggests, the ascending colon runs in an direction. It turns in a direction just beneath the and then becomes the descending colon. The descending colon connects to the rectum at the most posterior region of the abdomen. Consolidation of water material is the primary function of the large intestine. Most of the water that remains in the digested food is removed during this process. Varieties of bacteria inhabit the large intestine. These bacteria ferment any remaining carbohydrates and produce vitamin K, which is then absorbed into the blood. The compacted waste (feces) exits the body through the anus.

The <button class='glossary-text'>liver</button> is the largest organ in the abdominal cavity. The liver is located in the cranial abdomen, immediately posterior to the <button class='glossary-text'>diaphragm</button>. It contains four primary lobes. The left <button class='glossary-text'>lateral</button> lobe is on the left side of the pig and covers the stomach. The left <button class='glossary-text'>medial</button> lobe is immediately adjacent to the left lateral lobe. The right medial lobe is adjacent to the left medial lobe and is next to the body wall. The right lateral lobe is located on the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> side of the liver.

The liver is a highly vascular structure. Part of the blood supply to the liver is a system of veins known as the portal system. In the portal circulation, blood from the digestive organs, the stomach, and the large and <button class='glossary-text'>small intestines</button> enters the liver through the portal vein. The portal vein branches repeatedly into smaller and smaller vessels that finally feed into tiny vessels called capillaries. The capillaries eventually rejoin to form the hepatic veins. The hepatic veins connect to the posterior vena cava, which returns the blood to the <button class='glossary-text'>heart</button>. This system of veins-capillaries-veins enables the cells of the liver to perform many of their functions.

The <button class='glossary-text'>gallbladder</button> is a small, saclike structure located in a depression on the dorsal surface of the right medial liver lobe. The gallbladder, which appears as a green sac in adults, is a storage organ for bile. Bile is the digestive juice that is produced by the liver to emulsify fat. The cystic duct emerges from one end of the gallbladder. This duct functions as the passageway for bile. The cystic duct joins the hepatic duct as it emerges from the liver. Together they form the common bile duct, which carries bile to the small intestine.

pageData.subTitle: Circulatory System
pageData.text: The circulatory system consists of a four-chambered and an elaborate system of arteries, veins, and capillaries. It is surrounded by an opaque membrane, which is the . A fluid that lubricates and protects the heart is contained within the pericardium (3). The heart is composed of cardiac muscle. In essence, the heart is two separate pumps joined together. The left side of the heart pumps blood throughout the systemic circulation, while the right side of the heart pumps blood throughout the pulmonary circulation. These circuits will be discussed later.

The four chambers in the heart are the two atria and the two ventricles. We will discuss each area of the heart by following the flow of blood as it passes through this organ. We will describe the blood flow as it occurs in the animal after birth. Venous blood enters the heart through the (21), which is a thin-walled, saclike structure that receives blood from the large veins. Most of the blood (approximately 70%) that enters the atrium passes immediately into the (22). The remaining volume is forced into the ventricle as the atrium contracts. As the atrium relaxes and the ventricle begins to contract, a three-leafed valve (tricuspid valve) slams shut and prevents blood from flowing back into the atrium.

The right ventricle is a muscular chamber that generates enough force to push blood throughout the pulmonary circulation. Blood is forced into the pulmonary artery when the right ventricle contracts. The pulmonary semilunar valve prevents blood from flowing back into the ventricle. This valve consists of a set of three, pocket-like flaps that face into the artery. Blood reenters the heart through the pulmonary vein and into the (23) after it passes through the pulmonary circulation. Most of the blood that enters the left atrium flows freely into the (24). Similar to the right side of the heart, the remaining blood volume is forced into the ventricle during atrial contraction. The bicuspid valve prevents blood from passing back into the atrium. Two leaf-lets are present on this valve. The left ventricle has the thickest walls and is the strongest chamber of the heart. During contraction, it must generate enough pressure to force blood throughout the systemic circulation. The aortic semilunar valve prevents blood from reentering the ventricle while the left ventricle contracts and blood is transferred into the muscular aorta. The interatrial septum is located between the left atrium and the right atrium. A hole known as the foramen ovale is present in the septum of the mammalian fetus. The foramen ovale allows blood to bypass the pulmonary circulation by moving from the right atrium into the left atrium. This opening closes after birth. An embryonic vessel, the ductus arteriosus, is also present in the mammalian fetus. This vessel shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta, so that it bypasses the pulmonary circulation.

The arteries and the veins are the vessels through which blood flows. Artery walls contain smooth muscle and elastic fibers. This combination allows for the maintenance of a relatively constant blood pressure by expanding slightly as the contraction of the <button class='glossary-text'>heart</button> forces blood through the arteries. They spring back to their original shape as the heart relaxes.

Veins have few elastic fibers and little smooth muscle; they can expand to accept blood but cannot recoil. One-way valves prevent blood from flowing backward in the veins. Between the arteries and veins is a network of microscopic vessels, the capillaries. The exchange of nutrients and wastes between the blood and the cells occurs at the capillary network. The network of arteries, veins, and capillaries can be divided into two systems: the pulmonary circulation and the systemic circulation.

The pulmonary circulation begins at the pulmonary artery as the blood exits the <button class='glossary-text'>right ventricle</button>. At this point, the blood is rich in carbon dioxide and low in oxygen. This blood enters the <button class='glossary-text'>lungs</button>, where it gives up the CO<sub>2</sub> and takes on O<sub>2</sub>. It then returns to the <button class='glossary-text'>left atrium</button> via the pulmonary vein.

The systemic circulation is more complex (Figure 1). It begins as blood exits the via the aorta. The aorta arches to the pig’s left as it exits the . (This arch to the left is characteristic of all mammals). A number of arteries branch off from the aorta as it exits the heart. These vessels are the coronary arteries, which supply the heart itself with freshly oxygenated blood. Two arteries branch off from the aorta at the top of the arch. The brachiocephalic trunk is the first artery, which soon branches to form the right subclavian artery and the bicarotid trunk. The bicarotid trunk divides and becomes the left and right carotid arteries, which supply blood to the head and neck. The subclavian arteries supply blood to the (15) and (17).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of pulmonary circulation in the fetal pig, identifying the subscapular artery, subclavian artery, brachiocephalic artery, superior mesenteric artery, renal artery, gonadal arteries, iliolumbar artery, external iliac artery, common carotid arteries, aorta, coronary arteries, descending aorta, coeliac artery, and umbilical arteries

pageData.text: The aorta turns in a direction and runs along the surface of the body cavity as the dorsal aorta. Arteries that supply blood to the organs in the body cavity arise at various points along the dorsal aorta. One pair of branches, the renal arteries, supplies the (14) with blood. The dorsal aorta finally divides into a pair of iliac arteries, which supply the pelvis and the hind legs. The main artery of the leg, the femoral artery, is a major branch of the iliac artery. There is an additional pair of arteries that branches from the dorsal aorta in the fetal pig. These carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation and nutrient absorption (remember that the are not functional in the fetal pig). The umbilical arteries close at birth, and the portions to the bladder become part of the ligament of the bladder.

Blood returns to the <button class='glossary-text'>heart</button> via the venous system. Blood from the parts of the body posterior to the heart reenters the <button class='glossary-text'>right atrium</button> through the posterior vena cava. In the fetal pig, oxygenated blood flows from the placenta through the <button class='glossary-text'>umbilical vein</button>, passes through the <button class='glossary-text'>liver</button>, and then into the posterior vena cava. Blood from the hind legs enters the posterior vena cava through the femoral veins, which are parallel to the femoral arteries. Blood passes through the kidneys as it flows up the posterior vena cava. Blood filtered by the kidneys enters through the renal veins. Follow the posterior vena cava in an <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> direction to see that there are a number of smaller veins that receive blood from the abdominal viscera and enter the posterior vena cava.

As the posterior vena cava passes the liver, blood from the portal system enters into it via the hepatic veins. The portal system is a network of veins that collects blood from the intestine, <button class='glossary-text'>stomach</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>pancreas</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>spleen</button>. The blood is then passed through a network of capillaries in the liver, where the blood is filtered. Anterior to the heart, blood flows through the jugular and subclavian veins, into the anterior vena cava, and then into the right atrium.

pageData.subTitle: Urinary System
pageData.text: The urinary system filters the blood; recovers sugars, minerals, and water; and eliminates toxic waste from the body. The kidneys filter the blood. Some of the dissolved components and water will leave the bloodstream and enter the urinary pathway. They remove wastes from the blood using tiny functional units known as nephrons. The kidneys are protected and cushioned by a layer of fat.The ureter emerges from the kidney and conducts liquid waste into the (16). The urinary bladder is a thick-walled, muscular sac that serves as a reservoir for urine. The urethra emerges from the bladder as a single tube and conducts wastes to the exterior environment. In female pigs, the urethra opens into the urogenital sinus, which then passes wastes to the outside through the urogenital orifice. In male pigs, the urethra is joined by the two vasa deferentia that come from the . It then passes to the outside through the penis.

pageData.question: Blood is filtered by which of the following organs?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Blood is filtered by the liver as well as the kidneys.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the passage of waste through the urinary system?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The dissolved components and water from blood will leave the bloodstream and enter the urinary pathway via the kidneys, which then conduct the resulting liquid waste through the ureters to the urinary bladder for excretion from the body through the urethra.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: During its route through the cardiovascular system, blood is passed through a network of capillaries in the liver, where it is filtered. The urinary system also filters the blood; it recovers sugars, minerals, and water, and eliminates toxic waste from the body. The kidneys filter the blood. Some of the dissolved components and water will leave the bloodstream and enter the urinary pathway. They remove waste from the blood using tiny functional units known as nephrons. The ureter emerges from the kidney and conducts liquid waste into the urinary bladder. The urinary bladder is a thick-walled, muscular sac that serves as a reservoir for urine. The urethra emerges from the bladder as a single tube and conducts waste to the exterior environment. In male pigs, the urethra is joined by the two vasa deferentia that come from the testes. It then passes to the outside through the penis.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: During its route through the cardiovascular system, blood is passed through a network of capillaries in the liver, where it is filtered. The urinary system also filters the blood; it recovers sugars, minerals, and water, and eliminates toxic waste from the body. The kidneys filter the blood. Some of the dissolved components and water will leave the bloodstream and enter the urinary pathway. They remove waste from the blood using tiny functional units known as nephrons. The ureter emerges from the kidney and conducts liquid waste into the urinary bladder. The urinary bladder is a thick-walled, muscular sac that serves as a reservoir for urine. The urethra emerges from the bladder as a single tube and conducts waste to the exterior environment. In male pigs, the urethra is joined by the two vasa deferentia that come from the testes. It then passes to the outside through the penis.

pageData.subTitle: Reproductive System
pageData.text: The gonads are the primary reproductive organs. These organs are the <button class='glossary-text'>ovaries</button> in females and the <button class='glossary-text'>testes</button> in males. Accessory sex organs are also present in both males and females.

In the female, the small, paired ovaries are contained within the body cavity. They are located <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> to the <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button>. The ovaries are small, oval organs in the fetal pig. The produc-tion of the female sex hormones, estrogen and progesterone, occurs in the ovaries. They contain primitive germ cells that will become ova at sexual maturity. At birth, the ovaries of female mammals contain all the ova the individual will ever ovulate and more. The pig can release as many as 10 to 12 ova during ovulation. All these ova may be fertilized, leading to multiple births. In the mature sow, the ovary resembles a cluster of grapes because of the large number of mature follicles present. The oviduct is a small tube that transports egg cells from the ovary to the uterus. The oviducts extend from each ovary to the horns of the uterus. The muscular uterus of the pig contains two long, tubular uterine horns and a small uterine body. (The uterus of humans has a large body but no horns.) The uterus serves as the site of fetal implantation and development in humans. The long uterine horns serve this purpose in pigs.

The uterus opens into the vagina via the cervix, which is a constricted muscular region between the body of the uterus and the vagina. The cervix seals the uterus during pregnancy, provides a passageway for sperm into the uterus, and acts as a barrier to infection. The vagina is a muscular tube that functions as a receptacle for semen during copulation. The vagina opens into the urogenital sinus. This sinus passes to the outside through the urogenital orifice.

In males, the paired <button class='glossary-text'>testes</button> are responsible for the production of sperm and the production of androgens, the male sex hormones. The testes are held outside the body in a saclike structure, the <button class='glossary-text'>scrotum</button>, which is located <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> to the <button class='glossary-text'>anus</button>. The scrotum protects the testes and controls their temperature. Sperm do not develop properly at the temperatures found inside the abdominal cavity. The epididymis is a coiled, tubular structure that lies along one side of the testis. The epididymis is a sperm storage and maturation site. The vas deferens connects the epididymis to the urethra. The accessory male glands consist of the paired seminal vesicles and the bulbourethral glands. The seminal vesicles are located on either side of the prostate, which is a small flat gland at the junction of the urethra and the vas deferens. The bulbourethral glands are two long glands located at the junction of the urethra and penis. These glands secrete fluids that nourish and protect the sperm. Sperm leave the body through the penis during ejaculation. The testes may not be completely descended into the scrotum in the fetal pig. The testes may be found at any level, from just inside the body cavity to the scrotum.

This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for each activity closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including using appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.desc: flammable symbol
pageData.altText: flammable symbol
pageData.text: Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as a disinfectant.

pageData.desc: Using a scalpel

pageData.text:
Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:
  1. Clean the counter or work space thoroughly before and after the dissection using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).
  2. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
  3. Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
  4. Spread the absorbent pad blue-side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
  5. In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen.

• Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal:
    • Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
    • Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
    • Always use a sharp blade.
    • Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
    • Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
    • Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup>®</sup>
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup>®</sup> have found that the solution is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup>®</sup> specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well- ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup>®</sup> also means that, in most localities, there are no mandated disposal requirements.

pageData.desc: warning symbol
pageData.altText: warning symbol
pageData.text: Carolina’s Perfect Solution® causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and . Do not ingest the specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between activities, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

Clean and sanitize the work area.
Obtain the materials needed for the dissection (i.e., from the materials kit, the dissection kit, and those that are needed but not supplied).
Place the absorbent pad on the work area.
Place the foam tray in the middle of the pad.

Place the dissection mat to the side in view from your work area. The numbers in bold in the pig investigation refer to the numbers on the dissection mat. The mat has two sides with identical numbers: an exterior and a dissected view of the pig. Please use the appropriate side of the mat when referring to the numbers.
In Activity 1, you will measure the fetal pig to determine its gestational age. You will then examine and identify the external anatomy of the head and trunk.
Using a piece of twine, measure the pig from the nose tip to the <button class='glossary-text'>tail</button> base. Make sure to follow the curved spine.
Measure the length of the twine with a metric ruler. Use Table 2 to determine the age of the pig.

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Study the exterior of the animal, and take a photo of the <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> external anatomy of the pig.
Examine the hooves of the pig. Note the number and shape of the toes.
The pig can be divided into four sections: the head, neck, trunk, and tail (Figure 3).

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Diagram labeling the head, thorax, trunk, and tail on a fetal pig as well as the pinna, eye, nares, tongue, shoulder, wrist, forelegs, elbow, abdomen, teats, umbilical cord, hind legs, knee, foot, ankle, and anus

pageData.text: First, locate the snout. This structure ends in a flat, platelike tip that consists of cartilage.The paired external <button class='glossary-text'>nares </button> (3) located on the end of the snout serve as the passageway for airflow into the nasal cavity.

Look at the mouth. Note that the upper lip is thickrimmed, and the lower lip is smaller and more pointed. Look into the mouth and find the tongue (4). Teeth also may be present, depending on the age of your specimen.

The roof of the mouth (the hard palate) consists of a thin layer of tissue covering a base of bone and cartilage that separates the mouth cavity from the nasal cavity. Use a probe to examine this feature.
Examine the (2) and the upper and lower eyelids. The nictitating membrane is the third eyelid. This membrane covers the portion of the eye and helps keep it clean.
Moving in a forward direction from the inner corner of the eye, make a small incision in the upper and lower eyelids.
Open the eyelids to locate the nictitating membrane.
Locate and examine each (1).
Examine the external auditory meatus, the small opening in the ear.
Cut the (9) about 2 cm (3/4”) from the abdomen.

typeBefore.text: The trunk of mammals is divided into the (15) and the (16). The forelegs are connected at the (5) below the neck. On the foreleg, the bends posteriorly at the (6) . As you move proximally along the limb, you can see that it bends anteriorly at the (7). Two rows of (8) (teats) are present on the abdomen.

pageData.text: Examine the cut cord, and locate the blood vessels.

The (18) are behind the umbilical cord. They are very similar to the forelegs. The foot bends anteriorly at the (12), and the leg bends posteriorly at the (10). The (20) is beneath the tail (13). The anus is the opening of the digestive tract. Using Figure 4 and the pictures on the dissection mat, determine the sex of your specimen.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Diagram illustrating differences between male and female fetal pigs, with labels for the umbilical cord, teats, and anus on both; the urogenital opening and scrotum on the male; and the genital papilla on the female
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram illustrating differences between male and female fetal pigs, with labels for the umbilical cord, teats, and anus on both; the urogenital opening and scrotum on the male; and the genital papilla on the female

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will make a midsagittal cut along the <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button> surface of the fetal pig and examine its internal structures.

Place your pig in <button class='glossary-text'>dorsal</button> recumbancy, so that it can be opened to examine the internal anatomy (dorsal-side down, <button class='glossary-text'>ventral</button>-side up).
Tiof. Repeat the process for the hind legs. (Twine can be used if preferred or if you need to reinforce the rubber band ties.)

Using forceps, grasp the <button class='glossary-text'>umbilical cord</button> and pull up slightly. Use a scalpel or the scissors to make an incision about 1 cm <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> to the umbilical cord and along the midventral line of the body (see the dissection mat). Continue the incision toward the neck.

pageData.desc: Cutting a specimen

pageData.text: Continue the incision toward the <button class='glossary-text'>thoracic cavity</button>.

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: The ribs and sternum of the fetal pig are composed of cartilage. Cartilage can be cut using dissecting scissors. Pull the ribs apart to expose the organs in the chest cavity. Take a photograph of the internal anatomy now that the chest and are open. You can now see the (4), which is enclosed by the (3), a whitish, saclike membrane (Figure 5). The (5) are visible on either side of the heart.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Internal diagram of the fetal pig, labeling the trachea, thyroid gland, lungs, diaphragm, stomach, pancreas, intestines, larynx, thymus (partially removed), heart, liver, umbilical vein, umbilical cord, umbilical artery, and bladder
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Internal diagram of the fetal pig, labeling the trachea, thyroid gland, lungs, diaphragm, stomach, pancreas, intestines, larynx, thymus (partially removed), heart, liver, umbilical vein, umbilical cord, umbilical artery, and bladder

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Carefully cut through the neck muscles until you see a whitish tube the size of a pencil. This tube is the (19). Take another photograph of the internal anatomy now that the trachea is exposed. The (2) is on each side of the trachea and extends over the heart.
Locate the (1), which is a brown, oval structure on top of the trachea.

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Remove both the thymus and the thyroid. Take another photo of the internal anatomy to show it without the thymus and thyroid.
Following , make a shallow, approximately 3 mm (1/8”) incision around the umbilical cord (a u-shaped cut for a male pig and a circle for a female pig).
Note: Use scissors to avoid cutting into the internal organs.
Continue the incision toward the pubic region and the <button class='glossary-text'>anus</button> (Figure 6).
Expose and examine the shiny, semitransparent peritoneum.
Cut through the pubis to expose the structures that lie beneath it.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Broken lines on a diagram of the lower pig abdomen to guide making incisions around the umbilical cord for male and female pigs, continuing the incision toward the pubic region, anus, and across each leg
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Broken lines on a diagram of the lower pig abdomen to guide making incisions around the umbilical cord for male and female pigs, continuing the incision toward the pubic region, anus, and across each leg

pageData.text: In Activity 3, you will examine and identify the structures of the fetal pig respiratory system. As you dissect, you will cut into the <button class='glossary-text'>trachea</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>lungs</button> to observe their internal structures.
Locate the (18). The larynx is the hard, enlarged region of the (19) (
Carefully cut open the larynx. Locate the fibrous cords in the larynx. These cords are hard to identify.
Examine the trachea by cutting in between the cartilage rings. The trachea is lined with ciliated cells.
Locate the (20). Follow the trachea to the . Locate the bronchi.
Note that the inside lungs are divided into sections known as lobes. Examine the lobes of the lungs. There are four lobes on the right side and three on the left.
Cut open the lungs. Locate the bronchial tubes, which divide into secondary bronchi, then into bronchioles, and finally into very fine tubes that lead to microscopic air sacs (alveoli).

Lift the <button class='glossary-text'>heart</button>, and locate the junction where the lungs and blood vessels seem to merge. The pulmonary veins and arteries enter and leave the lungs through this location.
Locate the <button class='glossary-text'>diaphragm</button>. Manipulate the diaphragm, and note the flexibility.

In Activity 4, you will examine and identify the structures of the fetal pig digestive system. As you dissect, you will examine the mouth, as well as the internal and external structures of the <button class='glossary-text'>liver</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>stomach</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>small intestine</button>.

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Open the mouth and use the scissors to cut through the jaws at the joints on each side. Take a photograph of this open mouth.

The hard and soft palates prevent food from entering the nasal cavity (Figure 7). The hard palate is <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> to the soft palate. Locate the hard and soft palates.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Diagram of a pig’s open mouth, identifying the hard palate, tongue, epiglottis, soft palate, and tooth
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Diagram of a pig’s open mouth, identifying the hard palate, tongue, epiglottis, soft palate, and tooth

pageData.text: Locate the epiglottis, and push it back and forth to see how it works. Food is swallowed and passed to the <button class='glossary-text'>stomach</button> through the <button class='glossary-text'>esophagus</button>. The esophagus passes through the <button class='glossary-text'>thoracic cavity</button> behind the <button class='glossary-text'>trachea</button> and attaches to the stomach (Figure 8).

pageData.desc: Figure 8: Labeled diagram of a pig’s digestive system, identifying the diaphragm, descending aorta, pancreas, small intestine, jejunum, ileum, umbilical arteries, bladder, umbilical vein, large intestine, spleen, and stomach
pageData.altText: Figure 8: Labeled diagram of a pig’s digestive system, identifying the diaphragm, descending aorta, pancreas, small intestine, jejunum, ileum, umbilical arteries, bladder, umbilical vein, large intestine, spleen, and stomach

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Locate and photograph the (6).

Identify the four primary lobes of the liver.
  • The left lobe is on the left side of the pig and covers the stomach.
  • The left lobe is immediately adjacent to the left lateral lobe.
  • The right medial lobe is adjacent to the left medial lobe and is next to the body wall.
  • Lift the liver and turn it toward the pig’s left to locate the right lateral lobe.
Hold the tip of the left medial lobe with a pair of forceps, cut a piece with the scalpel or scissors, and examine it.
Locate the portal vein. This vein can be identified if the liver is lifted.

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Locate and photograph the (13).
Examine the cystic duct that emerges from one end of the gallbladder.

Remove the liver by cutting the <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> vena cava, the portal vein, the common bile duct, and the connective tissue holding the liver. Be careful to avoid cutting the esophagus, which leads to the stomach.
After you remove the liver, you will see the stomach in the anterior left side of the <button class='glossary-text'>abdomen</button>.
Find the cardiac sphincter at the junction of the stomach and the esophagus.
Cut the stomach open.
Exam the meconium if present.
Identify the pyloric sphincter, which is located at the end of the stomach.

pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: The and the (8) are next to the stomach. Take a photograph encompassing these organs.
Remove the stomach and spleen by cutting the esophagus above the stomach and cutting the <button class='glossary-text'>small intestine</button> just below the pyloric sphincter.
Lift the main portion of the small intestine, so that you can easily view the pancreas (15)—an elongated, granular, structure that is lighter in color than the intestines or the stomach.
Examine the small intestine (10).
Find the <button class='glossary-text'>ileum</button> and locate the ileocecal valve at the junction of the ileum and the <button class='glossary-text'>large intestine </button>.
Cut open and look inside a section of the small intestine.

Remove the small intestine by cutting it at its junction with the large intestine above the cecum. Carefully cut away the connective tissue (mesentery) that holds the intestine in place. Lift the small intestine and pancreas from the abdomen as a unit. The large intestine will be clearly visible. Identify the parts of the large intestine:
  • The spiral colon
  • The ascending colon
  • The descending colon
Find the rectum. It is a dark, straight tube that opens to the exterior environment through the <button class='glossary-text'>anus</button>.
In Activity 5, you will examine and identify the structures of the fetal pig <button class='glossary-text'>heart</button>.
Locate the () in the (4).
Carefully peel away the <button class='glossary-text'>pericardium</button>.
Locate the (21) on the pig’s right (your left).
Locate the (22).
Locate the pulmonary artery.
On the other side of the heart, locate the pulmonary veins returning to the heart.
Locate the (23) and the (24).
In Activity 6, you will examine and identify the structures of the fetal pig urinary system. As you dissect, you will remove and cut the kidney longitudinally to observe its internal structures.
Using the scissors, carefully cut through the muscle and bone in the pelvic girdle region to expose the urinary and reproductive systems.
When the legs of the pig lie flat on either side, the most <button class='glossary-text'>posterior</button> region of the abdominal area will be exposed.
Identify the bean-shaped (14). These are covered with peritoneum, which will need to be peeled away to see them well (Figure 9 for female pigs, Figure 10 for male pigs).

pageData.desc: Figure 9: Diagram of a female pig’s renal and reproductive systems, labeling the ureter, ovary, oviduct, uterine horn, uterine body, vagina, urogenital sinus, anus, genital papilla, pubis (cut), urethra, bladder, umbilical arteries, umbilical vein, round ligament, gonadal vein, gonadal artery, kidney, renal artery, and renal vein
pageData.altText: Figure 9: Diagram of a female pig’s renal and reproductive systems, labeling the ureter, ovary, oviduct, uterine horn, uterine body, vagina, urogenital sinus, anus, genital papilla, pubis (cut), urethra, bladder, umbilical arteries, umbilical vein, round ligament, gonadal vein, gonadal artery, kidney, renal artery, and renal vein

pageData.text: Note: In female pigs, the urethra opens into the urogenital sinus. In male pigs, the urethra is joined by the two vasa deferentia that come from the <button class='glossary-text'>testes</button>. It then passes to the outside through the penis (Figure 10).

pageData.desc: Figure 10: Diagram of a male pig’s renal and reproductive systems, labeling the kidney, ureter, umbilical vein, urogenital opening, umbilical artery, penis scrotum, urethra, bulbourethral gland, head of epididymis, testis, tail of epididymis, pubis (cut), vas deferens, seminal vesicle, gonadal artery, gonadal vein, renal artery, and renal vein
pageData.altText: Figure 10: Diagram of a male pig’s renal and reproductive systems, labeling the kidney, ureter, umbilical vein, urogenital opening, umbilical artery, penis scrotum, urethra, bulbourethral gland, head of epididymis, testis, tail of epididymis, pubis (cut), vas deferens, seminal vesicle, gonadal artery, gonadal vein, renal artery, and renal vein

pageData.text: Try to locate the adrenal glands on the <button class='glossary-text'>anterior</button> surface of the kidneys. They may be difficult to locate in the fetal pig.
Remove one of the kidneys, and cut it in a longitudinal direction.

Examine the three regions of each kidney:
  • The renal cortex
  • The renal medulla
  • The renal pelvis
Follow the ureters from the kidney to the (16).
Identify the urethra.
Cut through the pubis to expose the structures that lie beneath it. Cut slowly and carefully, since the structures are easily damaged.
In Activity 7, you will examine and identify the structures of the fetal pig reproductive system, including identifying the sex of your specimen.
The gonads are the primary reproductive organs. Locate the gonads.
Identify the sex of the pig.

For a female pig:
  • Locate the . They’re to the (Figure 9).
  • Identify the oviducts and the uterus. The uterus can be found by following each oviduct from the ovary to where it joins a wide structure called the uterine horn. The two uterine horns come together to form the body of the uterus. You may need to move the bladder and urethra aside, because the uterus is located to these structures.
  • Examine the vagina, which is a muscular tube. The constricted region at the base of the uterus where it joins the vagina is the cervix.

In a male pig:
  • Identify the (Figure 10). This double sac contains the .
Note: The testes may not be completely descended into the scrotum in the fetal pig.

1. Palpate (examine by feeling) the scrotum. If the testes can be detected, then use the scissors to carefully open the scrotum and expose them. If the testes cannot be felt in the scrotum, then carefully search for them in the most posterior region of the body cavity.
  2. Locate the epididymides.
  3. Locate the penis externally, and use scissors to cut through the skin and underlying tissue, in a posterior direction, to obtain a better view.
  4. Identify the vas deferens. To do this, relocate the urethra first. It starts at the base of the bladder, which has already been identified earlier in the dissection. Part of the vas deferens makes a dorsal loop over the ureter at the base of the bladder, and from there, the vas deferens and urethra course together until they merge.
  5. Follow the vas deferens to the urethra.
  6. Attempt to locate the bulbourethral glands at the junction of the urethra and the base of the penis.

text: Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag in an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air-dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.

Sanitize the work space with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.content: Figure 1. The arteries of a fetal pig
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of pulmonary circulation in the fetal pig, identifying the subscapular artery, subclavian artery, brachiocephalic artery, superior mesenteric artery, renal artery, gonadal arteries, iliolumbar artery, external iliac artery, common carotid arteries, aorta, coronary arteries, descending aorta, coeliac artery, and umbilical arteries
Figure 2: Diagram that demonstrates the common anatomical terms listed under “Orientation” on a fetal pig’s body

tableData.text: Toward the lower surface or belly
Near or toward a point of reference (e.g., the midline of the body)
Away from a point of reference (e.g., the midline of the body)
A long section that divides the body into right and left portions; a midsagittal section has equal right and left halves
A long section that divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of Activities 1-3 of the investigation. To prepare, set up the work area and dissection tools. In Activity 1, determine the gestational age of your specimen. Then, examine the external anatomy and determine the sex of the specimen. In Activity 2, cut open the ventral side of the specimen, and examine the thoracic cavity and the internal anatomy of the neck. Finally, cut open the pubic region. In Activity 3, cut open and examine the larynx, trachea and the lungs. Continue to Activity 4.

A map describing the procedural workflow of Activities 4-7 of the investigation. After completing Activity 3, in Activity 4, open and examine the mouth. Then, examine the liver and gallbladder. Next, cut open and examine the stomach. Then, examine the pancreas and spleen. Next, cut open and examine the small intestine. Finally, examine the large intestine. In Activity 5, locate and identify the parts of the heart. In Activity 6, remove the peritoneum, then cut open and examine the kidneys. Finally, examine the bladder and urethra. In Activity 7, determine the sex of your specimen, if you have not already. Then, examine the reproductive organs.

data.title: Abdomen
data.content: The part of the vertabrate body containing the digestive organs

data.title: Ankle
data.content: The joint that allows the movement of the foot

data.title: Anterior (cranial)
data.content: Toward the head

data.title: Anus
data.content: The opening where the gastrointestinal tract ends and waste exits the body

data.title: Diaphragm
data.content: A dome-shaped sheet of muscle that separates the chest cavity and abdominal cavities

data.title: Distal
data.content: Away from a point of reference

data.title: Diverticulum
data.content: An abnormal sac or pouch

data.title: Dorsal (superior)
data.content: Toward the back

data.title: Duodenum
data.content: The first and shortest section of the small intestine

data.title: Elbow
data.content: The joint that connects the forearm to the upper arm

data.title: Espophagus
data.content: A muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach

data.title: Eyes
data.content: A pair of sensory structure capable of receiving images

data.title: Foot
data.content: The terminal part of the leg

data.title: Forelimb
data.content: A limb that is situated anteriorly

data.title: Frontal plane
data.content: A long section that divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

data.title: Gallbladder
data.content: The sac in which bile from the liver is stored

data.title: Genital papilla
data.content: The small fleshy tubercle covering the urogenital opening of a female pig

data.title: Heart
data.content: A hollow muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body

data.title: Heterodont dentition
data.content: Having two or more types of teeth

data.title: Hind limbs
data.content: The posterior limbs of a quadruped

data.title: Ileum
data.content: The last portion of the small intestine

data.title: Jejunum
data.content: The middle part of the small intestine

data.title: Kidneys
data.content: Two bean-shaped organs are responsible for the three processes involved in urine production

data.title: Knee
data.content: The joint in the middle part of a hind limb

data.title: Large intestine
data.content: The tube that carries waste from the small intestine to the anus

data.title: Larynx
data.content: The respiratory passageway composed mainly of cartilage, voluntary muscle, and vocal cords that is used for breathing, swallowing, and talking; commonly referred to as the voice box

data.title: Lateral
data.content: Toward the side

data.title: Left atrium
data.content: One of the four chambers of the heart; it receives oxygenated blood from the lungs

data.title: Left ventricle
data.content: One of the four chambers of the heart; it pumps blood full of oxygen out to the body

data.title: Liver
data.content: The large organ that removes toxins, maintains blood sugar levels, and regulates blood clotting

data.title: Lungs
data.content: The organs located in the chest cavity responsible for adding oxygen to blood

data.title: Mammary papillae
data.content: The small projections near mammary glands containing milk ducts; in females only

data.title: Medial
data.content: Toward the midline

data.title: Nares
data.content: A pair of openings to the respiratory system; also called nostrils

data.title: Ovaries
data.content: The female gonads that produce eggs (ova)

data.title: Pancreas
data.content: The dual-function gland that secretes hormones into the bloodstream and pancreatic juice into the small intestine

data.title: Pericardium
data.content: The membrane that surrounds the heart

data.title: Pharynx
data.content: A muscular passageway of the respiratory and digestive systems; commonly referred to as the throat

data.title: Pinna
data.content: The outer ear

data.title: Posterior
data.content: Toward the tail

data.title: Proximal
data.content: Near or toward a point of reference

data.title: Right atrium
data.content: One of the four chambers of the heart; it receives deoxygenated blood

data.title: Right ventricle
data.content: One of the four chambers of the heart; it pumps blood low in oxygen to the lungs

data.title: Sagittal plane
data.content: A long section that divides the body into right and left portions; a midsagittal section has equal right and left halves

data.title: Scrotum
data.content: The small muscular sac that protects the testicles

data.title: Shoulders
data.content: The joints connecting the arms to the torso

data.title: Mandible
data.content: A jaw bone

data.title: Small intestine
data.content: The digestive system organ after the stomach where food is further digested and nutrients are absorbed

data.title: Spleen
data.content: The ductless organ involved in the production and removal of blood cells

data.title: Stomach
data.content: The muscular organ that receives food from the esophagus

data.title: Tail
data.content: The slender appendage that extends from the posterior end of the vertebrae; also called a post-anal tail

data.title: Testes
data.content: The male gonads that produce the hormone testosterone and the sperm

data.title: Thoracic cavity
data.content: The body cavity that contains the lungs, heart, and associated large blood vessels, together with much of the esophagus

data.title: Thorax
data.content: The part of the body between the neck and the abdomen; it includes the cavity enclosed by the chest

data.title: Thymus
data.content: The gland located inferior to the thyroid gland and anterior to the heart; it belongs to the lymphatic, immune, and endocrine systems

data.title: Thyroid
data.content: The butterfly-shaped endocrine gland located in the anterior neck

data.title: Trachea
data.content: A tube with C-shaped rings of cartilage that extends from the larynx to the bronchial tubes; commonly referred to as the wind pipe

data.title: Transverse plane
data.content: Perpendicular to the long axis

data.title: Umbilical arteries
data.content: The blood vessels that transport deoxygenated blood from fetus to placenta

data.title: Umbilical cord
data.content: The structure that extends from the abdomen of a fetus to the placenta of its mother; it contains one umbilical vein and two umbilical arteries

data.title: Umbilical vein
data.content: The blood vessel that carries nutrient- and oxygen-rich blood from placenta to the fetus

data.title: Urinary bladder
data.content: The organ that holds urine until it is ready to be released and expelled from the body

data.title: Ventral (inferior)
data.content: Toward the lower surface or belly

data.title: Wrist
data.content: The joint that connects the forearm to the hand
